page.body: The date is July 16, 1969. Humans have not yet walked on the moon. This is the story of how we put the first man on the moon and returned him safely to Earth.
page.heroCaption: The Moon looks beautiful in the evening sky

page.body: These three brave American astronauts have trained hard to get ready to fly to the Moon.
page.heroCaption: From left to right: Neil Armstrong, Michael Collins, Buzz Aldrin

page.body: The big day is finally here! Our hero astronauts climb aboard the massive Saturn Five rocket and blast off toward the Moon. Tap the button below to hear the rocket takeoff!

The astronauts flew a spacecraft made just for their mission to the Moon. The spacecraft was made of three parts, called "modules". The "Command Module", the "Service Module", and the "Lunar Module". Tap a part of the spacecraft above to see more.
page.heroCaption: Tap a part of the spacecraft to learn more

page.body: The Moon is a really long way from Earth. The total distance is about 237,000 miles. If it were possible, it would take 9 years to walk to the Moon. Even with a rocketship, it takes the astronauts four days to reach the Moon.

page.header: One small step for man, one giant leap for mankind
page.body: After nearly 10 years of hard work, great teamwork, NASA landed three astronauts on the Moon
page.heroCaption: The image on the left shows Buzz Aldrin climbing down the Lunar Module's ladder. The image on the right shows Buzz doing a science experiment on the Moon.

page.body: After spending X days on the Moon, our hero astronauts return to Earth. They reenter Earth's atmosphere in the Command Module, protected by a strong heat shield on the bottom of the spacecraft
page.heroCaption: Artist's draing of the Command Module reentering Earth's atmosphere

page.body: Our heros are welcomed back to Earth by the President of the United States, Richard Nixon. Nixon called the Apollo 11 mission "The greatest week in the history of the world since creation". At the very least the hard work and imagination of everybody at NASA helped mankind achieve what was once impossible.
page.heroCaption: President Nixon greets the Apollo 11 crew
